column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope X and BlueScope Buildings North America launched the 'Buildings of the Future' Accelerator Program this year, allowing nine global startups to leverage BlueScope's building and construction network to build, test and trial real solutions for the non-residential building sector. The Accelerator engaged startups, businesses and innovators with groundbreaking technology and ideas in advanced (non-repetitive) robotics and AI applications, sustainable and smart building solutions (including building design and management), integrated building solutions and customer experience technologies.
column20: Buildings of the Future, global startup, the non-residential building sector

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope is a consortium partner of the Australian Building 4.0 Cooperative Research Centre (CRC), a collaboration between government, industry and several universities working to improve building performance and supply chain efficiency. With a focus on digital solutions, new products, and processes for customer benefit, several of the Building 4.0 projects that commenced in 2020 have completed the scoping phase and are well into the research phase.
column20: Cooperative Research Centre, building performance, supply chain efficiency

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope partners with the Sustainable Building Research Centre at the University of Wollongong on climate-optimised building systems for unique Australian climates as part of the Australian Research Council (ARC) Research Hub for Australian Steel Innovation. This Steel Research Hub is advancing research across the Australian steel value chain from research and development to commercialisation, including evidence-based research on applying steel building products in lightweight and material-efficient construction systems to deliver durable, cost-effective and thermally efficient buildings for future climates.
column20: Sustainable Building Research Centre, University of Wollongong, climate-optimised building system

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope's Australian Steel Products is embarking on a program to plant trees that can be sustainably harvested to feed koalas at Symbio Wildlife Park in New South Wales. These include the Grey Gum, Cabbage Gum and Swamp Mahogany, primary food species for koalas. After identifying unoccupied land suitable for tree planting around the Port Kembla Steelworks, the team started with 160 trees last year and 380 trees in mid-2023. The trees are being kept to a maximum height of three metres to ensure all branches are within reach, with leaves expected to be harvested within 18 to 24 months.
column20: Tree, koala, Symbio Wildlife Park

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the Head Office Staff Club and the Diversity and Inclusion team, NS BlueScope Malaysia organised a Green Charity Walk to raise money for two children's homes. Thirty children from the children's homes, 184 employees, friends and family embarked on a five-kilometre walk around Botanical Park Shah Alam, Selangor. After the walk, MYR$5,000 in donations were presented to Rita Home and Shan Dai Home. The donations included monetary contributions from employees and the Company and essential items to address the immediate needs of the children's homes.
column20: Scholarship, BlueScope Foundation, Selection Committee

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Through the Head Office Staff Club and the Diversity and Inclusion team, NS BlueScope Malaysia organised a Green Charity Walk to raise money for two children's homes. Thirty children from the children's homes, 184 employees, friends and family embarked on a five-kilometre walk around Botanical Park Shah Alam, Selangor. After the walk, MYR$5,000 in donations were presented to Rita Home and Shan Dai Home. The donations included both monetary contributions from employees and the Company, as well as essential items to address the immediate needs of the children's homes.
column20: Green Charity Walk, Diversity and Inclusion Team, monetary contribution

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope is a proud founding partner of Sport Access Foundation (SAF). Established in 2017, SAF grants children and teenagers with disabilities to improve their access to and participation in sports. BlueScope has invested over $90,000 in SAF's annual grants program, operational costs, and innovative projects to improve the accessibility of sporting equipment and facilities.
column20: Sport Access Foundation, sport, sporting equipment

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Shanghai City Science and Technology School
column13: BlueScope Butler China has been building partnerships with local schools for several years to help students build skills, choose a career, and enter the workforce. This year, its Senior Engineering team worked with the Shanghai City Science and Technology School to prepare and deliver a course on engineering and construction for steel structures. More than 120 students and teachers visited BlueScope Butler China sites and exhibition halls to learn about types of building structures and their functions.
column20: Shanghai City Science and Technology School, student, engineering

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope's Western Port in Victoria, Australia, has a long-standing connection to the small community in which it operates. In FY2023, $14,000 was donated to local schools and an inter-school competition. A portion went towards supporting science, maths and school dux awards - given to students with the highest academic achievements. Western Port supported eight awards for primary and high school students.
column20: Inter-school competition, academic achievement, donation

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The BlueScope Foundation has donated US$100,000 to the Rock Island Bridge project in Kansas City to revitalise the historic West Bottoms area and connect the community to the Kansas Waterfront. The historic 1905 railroad bridge is being restored and turned into a public-use facility with trailhead services and entertainment space. The bridge is scheduled to open in late 2024.
column20: Rock Island Bridge project, West Bottom area, Kansas Waterfront

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: NS BlueScope Malaysia helped a local primary school improve its assembly hall, auditorium and library roofs, supplying 10.6 tonnes of ZincalumeÃÂ®. Under the CONNACTION program launched in 2016, BlueScope partners with its customers and stakeholders in sustainable corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities for the communities by connecting with DMI Building Products, which provides consultation, roll forming service and delivery of BlueScope material.
column20: CONNACTION program, primary school, DMI Building Product

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: For Martin Luther King Day 2023, nearly 100 volunteers, family members, and friends across Buildings North America sites volunteered to sort and bag fresh fruit and vegetables, package hygiene kits for the area's homeless shelters, and cook meals for local community members. In Jackson, Tennessee, BlueScope volunteers served around 100 free hot meals in a local soup kitchen to those in need.
column20: Martin Luther King Day, volunteering, fresh fruit

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: BlueScope's New Zealand and Pacific Island sites made their largest ever workplace-giving contribution to the Cyclone Gabrielle relief effort, contributing NZ $122,460 to the Red Cross Disaster Appeal. Employees directly contributed over NZ$11,000 and donated clothing, bedding and non-perishable items, which were transported by one of BlueScope's trucking contracting companies to the most affected area in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand.
column20: Cyclone Gabrielle, the Red Cross Disaster Appeal, workplace giving

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: NS BlueScope Indonesia collaborated with Al-Khairiyah University this year, supplying steel materials to fabricate shop-front booths for a dozen small and medium-sized local entrepreneurs at Cilegon. Students from the Technical Faculty participated in an incubator workshop where they learned more about BlueScope's products and how steel is used widely in everyday life.
column20: Al-Khairiyah University, steel material, local entrepreneur

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: This year, as part of BlueScope's Social Impact due diligence process, a desk-top review of potential modern slavery issues was completed across all its sites. Based on the findings of this assessment, BlueScope engaged a third-party provider to conduct a Labour and Working Conditions Audit in Malaysia (one of BlueScope's high-risk regions). Through its proactive due diligence process, BlueScope identified several modern slavery matters impacting some of its contract workers in its Malaysian business, which requires remediation. These matters were identified using a combination of worker interviews, confidential third-party surveys, investigations, and grievance lines.
column20: Modern slavery desktop review, Social Impact due diligence, modern slavery

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: BlueScope understands and responds to increasing stakeholder expectations for responsible supply chains. This year, BlueScope launched its new Responsible Sourcing Policy, which outlines its commitment to embed and promote ethical and responsible sourcing across BlueScope and its supply chain and demonstrates executive management accountability for supply chain sustainability.
column20: Responsible Sourcing Policy, stakeholder expectation, responsible supply chain

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: BlueScope refreshed its Supplier Code of Conduct this year to reflect strengthened environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance expectations. After translating the policy and amending the Code of Conduct into the languages its main suppliers use, BlueScope will carry out an extensive communication campaign.
column20: Supplier Code of Conduct, ESG, communication campaign

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column8: Global Procurement and Supply Chain learning community
column13: This year, BlueScope launched its Global Procurement and Supply Chain learning community, supporting its procurement teams with learning modules on all aspects of responsible sourcing, including modern slavery, and a shared platform for connection and sharing.
column20: Global Procurement and Supply Chain learning community, procurement team, modern slavery

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: During FY2023, 229 supplier assessments were completed, predominantly using the independent EcoVadis supplier assessment process. Where a supplier's assessment score is poor or has regressed, BlueScope actively works with them on corrective actions. Through these processes, BlueScope sees the highest risk in small-medium-sized suppliers and contractors operating in high-risk regions.
column20: EcoVadis, supplier assessment, corrective action

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Supplier risk assessments may result in revised conditions or escalation of significant issues within BlueScope and the supplier business. BlueScope recognises the potential impacts to people and the broader community that may result from terminating these business relationships. As such, BlueScope aims to ensure any such issues are addressed and remedied and practices put in place to avoid recurrence.
column20: Supplier risk assessment, business relationship, supplier business

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: BlueScope's Supply Chain Sustainability program is led by the Head of Group Procurement and Manager for Supply Chain Sustainability and delivered through business unit procurement teams. The Chief Financial Officer oversees the program and regularly reviews progress. New, major supply arrangements are overseen by a steering committee comprising the Chief Financial Officer, Chief Legal Officer, and representatives from relevant businesses.
column20: Supply Chain Sustainability program, supply arrangement, steering committee

Incidents of non-compliance concerning the health and safety impacts of products and services
Requirements for product and service information and labeling
column13: BlueScope's customers increasingly expect clear and transparent information about the sustainability performance of products. BlueScope conducts life cycle assessments for various products and provides information by national and international product evaluation schemes to inform decision-making.
column20: Life cycle assessment, transparent information, product evaluation

column6: Requirements for product and service information and labeling
column13: This year, BlueScope was excited to launch a new and refreshed COLORBOND steel colour palette in Australia. Australia's unique landscape inspired these new colours and brought a fresh direction. The refreshed palette includes two new colours in the COLORBOND steel cool roofing range: Dover WhiteTM and Southerly. A "cool roof" is made from materials designed to have high solar reflectance and thermal emittance to help keep the roof surface temperature cooler in the sun.
column20: COLORBOND, steel cool roofing range, solar reflectance

column6: Requirements for product and service information and labeling
column13: In many of its regions, BlueScope publishes Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs) to communicate the environmental impact of its products over their life cycle, including global warming potential (GHG emissions). EPDs can also support customers pursuing certification schemes such as eco-labels and rating tools. BlueScope's EPDs are compliant with International Standards ISO 14025 and EN 15804.
column20: Environmental Product Declaration, environmental impact, GHG emission

column6: Requirements for product and service information and labeling
column13: An ecolabel identifies products or services considered environmentally preferable within a specific category. Ecolabels can help customers and consumers quickly identify products that meet specific environmental performance criteria. As with EPDs, products with ecolabels can contribute points under green building rating tools such as Green Star and Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) frameworks. In September 2022, BlueScope China received Green Building Material Product Certification for Clean COLORBOND M steel.
column20: Ecolabel, environmental performance, green building
